title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text: It‚Äôs all DNA‚Äôs fault

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
next






Source







Source

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
In the past 20 years, CSI-style forensic analysis has taken quite a beating.
DNA is the gold standard for forensic evidence - a specific combination of genes is supposed to be unique to the individual, matches can be objectively determined with error rates that are quantifiable, and it could be used to reexamine evidence from old cases.
As organizations like the Innocence Project used DNA to revisit old cases, it became clear that there were major problems with the evidence used in criminal cases ‚Äì eyewitness testimony, false confessions, and shoddy forensics.
There were a number of very embarrassing cases where forensic evidence was shown to be faulty. As these cases happened, scientists started asking how this all went so wrong? Wasn‚Äôt forensics ultimately based in science? Weren‚Äôt there studies out there showing that forensic techniques had low error rates?

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Wire Cuts






CAT5 crimper with wire cutter







Cut wires









Digital scan of blade cut and wire cut

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text: A Specific Case ‚Äì Jimmy Genrich

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Motivation


At trial, O‚ÄôNeil testified that tools like the wire cutters found in Genrich‚Äôs residence were the only tools that could have been used to make the pipe bombs. ‚ÄúAgent O‚ÄôNeil opined that the three of Mr.¬†Genrich‚Äôs tools were the only tools in the world that could have made certain marks found on pieces from the four bombs,‚Äù Judge Gurley wrote in Monday‚Äôs opinion.


O‚ÄôNeil was asked specifically at trial what he meant by the phrase ‚Äúto the exclusion of any other tool.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat the individual jaw, the location within that jaw on that particular side, was identified as having cut the wire in question to a degree of certainty to exclude any other tool,‚Äù he said, according to court transcripts referenced in Gurley‚Äôs decision. O‚ÄôNeil said this was true of needle-nosed pliers used on the bomb, slip-joint pliers, as well as the wire cutter.


Source (emphasis added)

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
üß™Scientific Factors

Material Surface

Material type/characteristics
History (previous damage, etc.)

Tool Operational Surface

Material type/characteristics
Manufacturing Process
Mark type/frequency distribution



Scientifically, this could be boiled down to a combination of a statistics problem and a materials engineering problem: we need to understand the material surface (in this case, wire, which is likely copper or aluminium, and, if it‚Äôs insulated, we can probably get away with assuming the interior core is undamaged).
We also need to understand the tool ‚Äì how many cutting surfaces does the tool have? How do they interact? At what angle? How much force is required, and does additional force produce different results?
The manufacturing process for the tool‚Äôs operational surface is usually what forensics examiners claim gives each tool a unique set of markings. So, we have to understand how the tool is manufactured, where those markings might come from, and what types of markings are likely to be analyzed ‚Äì the relative frequency of different types, etc.

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Examiner Method


Between 2 and 4 cutting surfaces for each tool, \(s \in \{2, 4\}\)
Wires have 1-2 striated surfaces, \(w \in \{1, 2\}\)

text:

Test cuts made along the blade(s) of the tool
At least \(N_{ij} = b_i/d_j\) comparisons for each blade surface \(i\) and cut wire surface \(j\)
Manual alignment: estimate the minimum comparisons

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Science Begins at Home

My house has \(\approx\) 982 cm of (easily accessible) blade surface which might be used to cut wires. My dad has \(\approx\) 2243 cm of blade surface in his shop. No one in either house uses tools professionally.

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
üß™Scientific Factors

Interactions

Relative hardness
Angle
Force
Contact surface(s)
Deformation



Then, we need to understand interaction effects ‚Äì how do changes in tool and substrate material change the marks that are produced?
You can see how the number of factors very quickly gets out of control. Establishing the discipline from first principles is ‚Ä¶ difficult, to say the least. You could probably do it with a combination of time, stubbornness, and statistical inference, but there is always a chance that a new manufacturing method will be developed that will produce new types/classes of markings.
Ultimately, it seems likely that even with statistical inference, establishing the toolmark discipline from first principles is not possible, and it certainly doesn‚Äôt seem to be an effective use of time and funding.

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
section: üìê A Different Angle on the Problem
text:
üìê A Different Angle on the Problem

\(e^{(1)}\): error rate for a single comparison
\(e^{(N)}\): overall error rate, \(N\) comparisons
Calculate \(N\): # comparisons between tool and evidence
Ultimate question:
What does \(e^{(1)}\) need to be for \(e^{(N)}\) to be low1?

Low enough will be determined by courts‚öñÔ∏è, not statisticians‚Ä¶ ü´£

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Visual Examination

Adj. comparisons are non-overlapping \(\Rightarrow\) ‚Äúindependent‚Äù1
There are peak-valley dependence structures in profile data, but conditioning on tool/material/manufacturing, we would expect statistical independence between adjacent comparisons

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
section: So How Bad Is the Problem?
text:
So How Bad Is the Problem?
For error rate \(e\) and \(n\) comparisons
\[P(\text{no false positive errors}) = 1 - \left(1 - e\right)^n\]

Simple probability üé≤ strikes again!

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
section: So How Bad Is the Problem?
text:
So How Bad Is the Problem?

Estimated false positive error rate for striated comparisons from bullets and firing pins: 0.45 - 7.24%.

Pooled estimate: 2%
Not enough error rate studies on wires
Bullets have additional structure to facilitate alignment
Wires have additional complexity

shorter sequences
more dependence on angle



\(\Rightarrow\) 2% is a generous estimate‚Ä¶

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
section: So How Bad Is the Problem?
text:
So How Bad Is the Problem?
To keep the overall false positive rate under 10%‚Ä¶

2% Error -> 5 total comparisons.
Minimum of 15 required to do even a simple wire-cut analysis.

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Conclusions

Wire cut forensics are not scientifically sound using current analysis methods


but‚Ä¶ this problem shows up in database searches, too!

IAFIS (Integrated Automated Fingerprint ID System)
NIBIN (Ballistics Database)
NDIS (National DNA ID System) and CODIS (Combined DNA ID System)
PDQ (Paint Data Query)
FISH (Forensic ID System for Handwriting)

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Conclusions

Automatic intelligence algorithms are not a good substitute for investigative work
Example: Oregon

3 firearms examiners for the state
Most firearms evidence run through NIBIN first
Promising leads forwarded to examiners for manual assessment


This is a setup that could generate false-positives by design!

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Conclusions

Examiners should report and the defense should require

overall length/area of surfaces generated during the examination \((b)\)
total consecutive length/area of recovered evidence \((d)\)

Studies relating length/area of comparison surface to error rates are essential!

No available black-box error rate for wire cuts
Studies should be difficult, like casework!

Any database search used at any stage of the process should be disclosed along with

\(N\) items in the database used for comparison
Number of results returned as ‚Äòsimilar‚Äô (top 20? top 5?)
Protocols for confirmatory assessment

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Some Personal Motivation

My house has \(\approx\) 982 cm of (easily accessible) blade surface which might be used to cut wires. My dad has \(\approx\) 2243 cm of blade surface in his shop. No one in either house uses tools professionally.

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
section: Constructive Scientific ProofProof from first principles
text:
Constructive Scientific ProofProof from first principles



Understand

how tools make marks
tool wear over time
tool manufacturing processes
tool/material interaction
mark type/frequency distribution

Track

Frequency of tools in a local population



üòì


Scientifically, this could be boiled down to a combination of a statistics problem and a materials engineering problem: we need to understand the material surface (in this case, wire, which is likely copper or aluminium, and, if it‚Äôs insulated, we can probably get away with assuming the interior core is undamaged).
We also need to understand the tool ‚Äì how many cutting surfaces does the tool have? How do they interact? At what angle? How much force is required, and does additional force produce different results?
The manufacturing process for the tool‚Äôs operational surface is usually what forensics examiners claim gives each tool a unique set of markings. So, we have to understand how the tool is manufactured, where those markings might come from, and what types of markings are likely to be analyzed ‚Äì the relative frequency of different types, etc.
Then, we need to understand interaction effects ‚Äì how do changes in tool and substrate material change the marks that are produced?
You can see how the number of factors very quickly gets out of control, even before we start tracking the number of tools that exist locally.
Establishing the discipline from first principles is ‚Ä¶ difficult, to say the least. You could probably do it with a combination of time, stubbornness, and statistical inference, but there is always a chance that a new manufacturing method will be developed that will produce new types/classes of markings.
Ultimately, it seems likely that even with statistical inference, establishing the toolmark discipline from first principles is not possible, and it certainly doesn‚Äôt seem to be an effective use of time and funding.

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Personal Motivation

My house has \(\approx\) 982 cm of (easily accessible) blade surface which might be used to cut wires. My dad has \(\approx\) 2243 cm of blade surface in his shop. No one in either location is a craftsperson.

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Constructive Scientific Prooffrom first principles



Understand

how tools make marks
tool wear over time
tool manufacturing processes
tool/material interaction
mark type/frequency distribution

Track

Frequency of tools in a local population



üòì


Scientifically, we might boil this down to a series of engineering and materials science problems - understanding the types of marks which can occur on different types of tool materials through manufacture, wear, etc., and then understanding in turn how those tools transfer marks to other surfaces and how force, angle, and material hardness impact those marks.
Unfortunately, though, the number of different characteristics gets very quickly out of control and you end up with an exponential number of interactions very quickly.
Establishing the discipline from first principles is ‚Ä¶ difficult, to say the least. You could probably do it with a combination of time, stubbornness, and statistical inference, but there is always a chance that a new manufacturing method will be developed that will produce new types/classes of markings.
But, there are other ways to handle this problem.

title: Human Computer Data Interaction
text:
Attention



Focused vs.¬†Divided attention

Divided = multiple input streams must be processed (e.g.¬†driving a car)
Focused = single input stream

Attention shifts with gaze systematically throughout a visual stimulus
Information which is extraneous to the task may not be stored or remembered
